## p. (#5) ##################################################

PREFATORY NOTE
THIS eighty-first yearly issue of THE ENGLISH Catalogue of Books comprises
the titles (under authors, and subjects or titles) of works published during 1917,
and also of some received too late for inclusion in the eightieth issue.
The main entry for each book begins with the author's surname (if known)
in heavy type. As an index to these "Author" records, entries are also made
under the titles, commencing with their most important words (which usually
indicate the subjects with which the books deal), or with the first words; the
name or word under which the main entry appears is printed in italics in these
index entries, thus giving a reference to the place where the full information
about a book may be found. Main entries and index entries are in one alphabet.
Writers with compound names are entered under the first part of the name,
e.g. :-
Baring-Could (Sabine)
and accordingly must be looked for in that order. References are also made,
however, from the last part of the name.
It should be noted that Official and Parliamentary Publications mentioned
in this volume, with the exception of the Hydrographic Publications of the
Admiralty, can now be purchased directly from H.M. Stationery Office.
Attention is also drawn to the form of date adopted in the latter months of this
year ('17). This has resulted in a want of uniformity in the completed volume,
but was introduced to define more clearly that the number after the month
refers to the year of publication.
The publications of learned Societies are recorded in an Appendix.
The names and addresses of the Publishers of Great Britain and Ireland,
followed by those of the principal publishers in the United States and Canada,
will be found at the end of the volume. The telegraphic and cable addresses
and telephone numbers have been added when known.
Following the Preface is an analysis of the books of the year 1917, showing
in detail the number of works in each class of literature, and giving the proportions
of new books, translations, pamphlets, and new editions.
Hearty thanks are due to many publishers, secretaries, librarians, authors
and bibliographers who have assisted in making this book more correct and
comprehensive than it would have been otherwise.
The Editor will be glad to have particulars (author, title, size, price, publisher,
and month of publication) of any work which may have been omitted. Information
regarding each book should be given on a separate slip of paper or postcard.
It should be addressed to The Editor of THE ENGLISH CATALOGUE OF BOOKS,
"Publishers' Circular " Office, 19, Adam Street, Strand, London, W.C. 2.
THE EDITOR.
1918.
JUL 161918 398471

## p. (#7) ##################################################

ANALYSIS OF BOOKS
PUBLISHED DURING 1917 IN THE UNITED KINGDOM
THE PUBLISHERS' CIRCULAR AND BOOK-
SELLERS' RECORD records a total of 8,131
books as having been published during
the year 1917, a decrease of 1,018 volumes
compared with the output of 1916. The
falling off has been distributed unevenly
over all classes of literature with the
exceptions of Philology, Medicine, Agri-
culture, Domestic and Business, each
showing a small increase, and History
showing a comparatively large increase
of 147 items. These classes represent
subjects brought into prominence by the
continuance of the European War, as,
for instance, the necessity of word and
phrase books for the use of soldiers and
others, the demand on medical science,
the problem of production, the readjust-
ment of business and domestic life, and
the record, historical and general rather
than technical, of the War. The quality
of the 1917 output has maintained a
good level and, combined with so com-
paratively small a decrease in production
in face of unparalleled difficulties of
labour and materials, is a great tribute
to the vitality and enterprise of British
authors and publishers.
It should be noted that in the follow-
""
""
"
ing classes Education" includes only
books about educational theory and
practice, and not text books on special
subjects, which are classed elsewhere;
that under Music only works about
music are recorded; and that books
dealing generally with the European War
are classed under "History," while those
of a technical nature are placed under
the heading "Military and Naval." It
would be possible to swell the total to a
much greater figure by counting numerous
leaflets (Government and other),
ephemeral pamphlets, the publications
of borough councils and other local
government bodies, and musical texts.
While it is obvious that our total could
be increased greatly by the inclusion of
all this literary protozoa, the figures
would not represent so accurately the
book publishing activity of the United
Kingdom.
The following totals of the last ten
years are of considerable interest :-
New
books.
Year.

In these tables each publication is
counted as one, whether it is in one or
more volumes. Serials that appear later
as a collected volume are counted as an
ordinary book on the appearance of that
volume; so that, for example, the series
of "Statutory Rules and Orders" issued
by the Government, and amounting to
several hundred in the year, are counted
as one item on the appearance of the
annual collected volume. The same
rule applies to volumes of magazines, &c.
Further detailed information regarding
the year's publishing is supplied by the
appended analytical tables.

## p. 260 (#268) ############################################

[1917
THE ENGLISH CATALOGUE
DIRECTORY OF PUBLISHERS
Publishers are invited to send us their Telegraphic Addresses and Telephone Numbers.
Those sent will be found below between square brackets [ ], and separated from each other by a semicolon (;)
The Editor will be glad to be notified of any inaccuracy in the following lists for correction in subsequent volumes.
This list of Publishers, with their Addresses, has been compiled principally with a view to supplying
information regarding the books in the English Catalogue. This will explain the inclusion of some
firms in the list who can scarcely, in the strict acceptation of the term, be called Publishers, since the publication
of books forms only an occasional part of their business.

## p. (#284) ################################################



## p. (#285) ################################################

Every Bookseller, Librarian and
Book Collector should read
The
PUBLISHERS' CIRCULAR
and
BOOKSELLERS' RECORD
the organ of the British Book Trade.
The weekly paper which keeps its readers in touch
with new or interesting movements in the Book World
by means of articles, notes, announcements, reviews,
lists of new publications and publishers' advertisements.
An unequalled medium for acquiring or disposing
of second-hand books, magazines and prints.
Published Every Friday .
Price 3d.
Home
15s. Od.
Annual Subscription
Abroad
17s. 6d.
All subscriptions expire at end of year, but may
commence with any issue, 34d. (Home) and 4d.
(Foreign) being deducted for each Saturday that
has passed since the beginning of the year.
Specimen Copy Post Free
-on application-
Office: 19, Adam St., Strand, London, W.C. 2.


## p. (#286) ################################################

THE ENGLISH CATALOGUE OF BOOKS
1801 TO 1917
Giving Author, Title, Subject, Size, Price, Month and Year of Pub-
lication and Publisher of over 500,000 Books issued in the United
Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. The early volumes were
published with separate Index Volumes-since 1890 the References
and Cross References have been arranged alphabetically in the
one volume.
The following is a complete list of THE ENGLISH CATALOGUE OF BOOKS
COVERING A PERIOD OF 117 YEARS, with details and the prices at which
copies can be supplied. The Volumes are sold separately or in long or
short sets.

THE
ENGLISH CATALOGUE
OF BOOKS
is published at the office of The
Publishers' Circular, Ltd. Price list
of the volumes covering the period
from 1801 to 1917 can be had by
writing to the following address:-
BING. CAT. DEPT. THE PUBLISHERS CIRCULAR, LTD.,
19. Adam Street, Strand, London, W.C. 2.
